What separates complex numbers from familiar numbers (the integers, the reals, etc.) is the declaration of a specific value i to represent the square root of negative one.

When we use this i term, now we can factor i out of several questions that previously were "undefined", then continue evaluating them with familiar methods.

This isn't just a clever workaround, this actually leads to a mathematically correct framework where we can define numbers, operations, relationships, and all of the familiar mathematics, and methodically, repeatably arrive at the correct solutions to a diverse range of problems. These solutions are even an essential "elementary" piece of most modern engineering, including electronics, physics, mechanical engineering, population modelling, and so forth.

There are two primary ways to represent a complex number. The first, more intuitively, is a real component plus an imaginary component multiplied by i. Alternatively, complex numbers can be represented in polar coordinates, with a scalar modulus times an argument (radian angle) relative to the real axis.

For every non-zero complex number, there are guaranteed to be exactly n n-th roots. For example, there are exactly 2 square roots of 1, 3 cube roots, 7 7-th roots, and so on.

One neat thing to notice, if you look at them on the complex plane, they all fall on the same circle and are evenly spaced out.

To try this out, you can enter any complex number below and see the list of its roots.
